Screenwriting Template for Google Docs

Every screenwriter starts with a blank page, but how you format that page can make or break your first impression with agents, producers, or contests. The good news? You don’t need expensive software to write a properly formatted script. With the right approach and template, Google Docs can become your go-to screenwriting tool—free, accessible, and industry-compliant.

Why Format Matters in Screenwriting

Hollywood follows strict rules for screenplay formatting—not just for aesthetics, but to determine pacing, readability, and runtime. One page of a screenplay roughly equals one minute of screen time. If your format is off, it throws everything off. Sloppy margins, inconsistent dialogue indentation, or improper scene headings signal amateurism instantly. Google Docs allows you to hit the standard with a few customizations and best practices.

Core Elements of a Proper Screenplay

Before diving into the how-to, it’s important to understand the anatomy of a screenplay. These are the essential formatting elements:

  • Scene Headings (Sluglines): INT. or EXT. + LOCATION – TIME
  • Action Lines: Describe visual actions, always in present tense
  • Character Names: Centered and capitalized
  • Dialogue: Centered beneath character names, narrow margins
  • Parentheticals: Short direction under the character name (optional)
  • Transitions: e.g., CUT TO: or FADE OUT.

How to Format a Screenplay in Google Docs

Step 1: Adjust Page Settings

Start with File > Page Setup. Set margins to the following:

  • Top: 1 inch
  • Bottom: 1 inch
  • Left: 1.5 inches
  • Right: 1 inch

This mirrors standard screenwriting layout that allows room for binding on printed copies.

Step 2: Choose the Right Font

Set your font to Courier New, 12 pt. This monospaced font is the industry standard, ensuring accurate page-to-minute estimation.

Step 3: Set Paragraph Styles for Elements

Use the Styles dropdown in Google Docs to create custom styles for each screenplay element:

  • Scene Heading: All caps, left aligned, no indent
  • Action: Regular text, left aligned, no indent
  • Character: Centered, all caps
  • Dialogue: Centered with 2.5" left and 2" right margins
  • Parenthetical: Centered, smaller indent under character name
  • Transition: Right-aligned, all caps

To create these styles manually, use Format > Paragraph styles > Options > Save as my default styles.

Step 4: Use Tables to Control Layout

For precision, many writers create a 1-row table with invisible borders to format dialogue:

  • Create a 1x1 table
  • Click inside, then go to Format > Table > Table properties
  • Set left/right cell padding to match industry indentations (usually 2.5” left and 2” right)
  • Remove the table border entirely

This allows you to easily align dialogue blocks without messing up the rest of the page layout.

Google Docs Screenplay Template (Copy and Use)

You can save time by starting from a premade Google Docs template. Here's one formatted with all the major elements:

  • Download a professional Google Docs screenwriting template
  • Make a copy to your Drive and begin editing
  • Use the built-in styles to stay consistent across pages

Alternatively, you can build your own from scratch and save it as a reusable template.

Tips to Maintain Industry Standards

  • Scene Headings: Always write in CAPS and start a new line
  • Transitions: Only use them when necessary
  • Character Names: Keep consistent spelling and capitalization
  • Dialogue: Shorter is better. Avoid overloading the page
  • Proofread: Typos in a script are dealbreakers

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Can I write an entire screenplay using Google Docs?

A: Yes. While it lacks built-in screenplay tools like Final Draft or Celtx, with manual styling or a template, Google Docs is fully capable of producing a professional script.

Q: Is Courier New mandatory for screenwriting?

A: Yes. Courier New 12pt is the industry standard. It ensures that your script's length equates closely to its screen time.

Q: Are there Google Docs add-ons for screenwriting?

A: Yes. Add-ons like Screenplay Formatter automate formatting with predefined styles and shortcuts.

Q: How do I export my script for submission?

A: Use File > Download > PDF for final submission or DOCX if an editable format is requested. Always check agent/publisher guidelines.

Q: How long should a screenplay be?

A: Most full-length screenplays are between 90–120 pages. Each page generally equals one minute of screen time.

Conclusion

Google Docs offers a surprisingly effective platform for screenwriting—if you know how to bend it to the industry’s needs. With the right font, spacing, and styles, you can create a script that looks and feels as professional as anything written in Final Draft. Save your setup as a template, master the formatting rules, and let your story shine from page one.
